BuckleyReprinted with permission at Earthfiles. Return to Part 1March 4, 2007 Wiltshire County, England - Continued from Part 1.A Field Report© 2006 by Andrew J. Buckley. All rights reserved.Left: Artist's impression of the mysterious girl seen by Gordon Stewart and Andy Buckleyat Wilcot Brow and Tawsmead Copse, Alton Priors, Wiltshire, England, on Wednesday,August 10, 2005. Right: 2005 drawing of "insectogram" crop formation by Gill Nicholas.The Vale of Pewsey, the village of Alton Priors is highlightednext to the red circle that marks the South Field. Also highlighted around the South Fieldare Tawsmead Copse, Woodborough Hill and the big East Field

on the other side of the brown country road.Fig. 9. Overlay of mysterious girl drawing on photograph of Tawsmead Copseand the curving edge of the South Field. Composite image © 2005 by Andrew J. Buckley.
Fig. 10. Artist's impression of mysterious girl.

Unusual checkerboard pattern on shirt front and on stockings.[ Editor's Note: Checkered shirts and high strangeness. Forty years ago in1967, there was a huge UFO flap in the Ohio River valley of the United States,including Point Pleasant, West Virginia. Residents there reported lots ofunidentified aerial lights and silver disks, both day and night, along with strangeflying creatures that resembled large humans with bat wings. That year, one ofthe most famous investigators of earth mysteries was John A. Keel. He went toPoint Pleasant and coined the term “Mothman” for the winged humanoidsbeing seen flying in the air. John Keel wrote a book about his investigationsentitled The Mothman Prophecies, published in 1976.In Chapter 10, Keel wrote about one woman being waked up by a strange manwalking around her bed. The woman told Keel that the mysterious man waswearing a "checkered shirt." Keel further wrote: "Bedroom phantoms incheckered shirts are old hat to investigators of psychic phenomena. I havecome upon this again and again. So often that I have written long articles aboutit. In some cases, these ghosts-in-plaid are accompanied by the odor ofhydrogen sulfide and sudden chills or sudden blasts of heat..." ] 11:20 AM, August 12, 2005 -Andy Discovers "Insectogram"

Fig. 11. Artist's impression of the 2005 Woodborough Hill/Tawsmead Copse "insectogram" wheat formation. Drawing by Gill Nicholas.
